text:
currently, usecases in modules are not named consistently: we have
<modulename>.<action>, <action>.<modulename> and even module.<modulename>.<action>.

i propose to change that to <modulename>.<action>. using "module" as a prefix
looks nice, but given that the ultimate goal seems to be to modularize as much
as possible, we might end up with all usecases in modules, at which point the
prefix becomes redundant.

Created attachment 18785
renames all bxe usecases to adhere to the form bxe.<action>

updated to revision 439238, please apply.
this patch includes fixes for documentation and example code all over the
source tree. to verify no usecases have been overlooked and to check your
custom pubs/modules, you can do this (on unix):
grep -ri --exclude "*svn-base" --exclude "*~" edit.bxe *
grep -ri --exclude "*svn-base" --exclude "*~" close.bxe *
grep -ri --exclude "*svn-base" --exclude "*~" edit.insertAsset *
grep -ri --exclude "*svn-base" --exclude "*~" edit.insertImage *

this patch introduces a subtle change in semantics: before, the
insertAsset|insertImage usecases had generic names (edit.*). they have been
changed to bxe.*, since they were always associated with bxe-specific
jxtemplates anyway. 
it might be worth moving those templates out of the bxe module altogether and
use generic functions some day.

Created attachment 18800
a list of renamed usecases for automated testing of your custom code

the file contains a list of all renamed modules. to ease the task of adapting
your your custom code, the following shell snippet will spit out all
occurrences of the old usecase names (for those blessed with a decent shell):
for i in `cat renamed-usecases.txt` ; do echo "### checking for occurrences of
\"$i\":" ;  grep -ri --exclude "*.svn*" --exclude "*entries" --exclude "*~"
--exclude "*orig" --exclude "*rej" "$i" * ; done | less

(In reply to comment #19)
> Created an attachment (id=18800) [edit]
> a list of renamed usecases for automated testing of your custom code

in order to find out the new names of the usecases, refer to the
usecase-policies.xml file of the default publication.
